Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2015, Broadening Participation. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow, and a plan to broaden participation of groups under-represented in science. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Jonathan B. Koch is "Invasion biology, population genomics, and adaptive evolution of spotted wing Drosophila (Drosophila suzukii)." The host institution is the University of Hawaii at Hilo (UHH), and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Donald Price. The Fellow will also collaborate on his research and training plan with Dr. Peter Follett of the USDA-ARS Daniel K. Inouye U.S. Pacific Basin Agricultural Research Center.

Biological invaders are a global problem when they become agricultural pests with both enormous economic as well as ecological impacts. Within a few generations of establishment some non-native species have been found to persist and adapt to novel environments, exhibit increased growth rates, and acquire behavioral traits that promote their invasion success. Drosophila suzukii (SWD) is such an invader. It is a world-wide agricultural pest and has also emerged as a model species to study the evolution of invasiveness. The fellowship research identifies the evolutionary mechanisms that have enabled SWD to invade and adapt to the mosaic of ecosystems found in Hawaii. Activities include a survey of SWD populations throughout the major Hawaiian Islands and genome sequencing. Elucidating the mechanisms that drive a biological invasion increases fundamental understanding of the genetic processes that promote the persistence of immigrant species and may promise approaches to mitigate the invasion.

Training goals include gaining experise in evolutionary biology, population genomics, and bioinformatics as well as career advancement activities. Educational outreach includes serving as a role model and mentor to graduate and undergraduate students and developing a K-6 curriculum addressing basic concepts in ecology, evolution, and conservation. The curriculum is intended for local Hawaii schools and freely available through the UHH NSF PRISM website. Public outreach includes producing a short documentary on the SWD invasion in Hawaii with GoPro technology, to be available on social media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Invasive species are a global dilemma, with their management to reach an estimated cost of $120 billion to the U.S. economy each year. Within a few generations of establishment, some invasive species have been found to persist and adapt to novel environments, exhibit increased growth rates, and acquire behavioral traits that promote their invasion success.  The Spotted Wing Drosophila (SWD), Drosophila suzukii, is a globally distributed invasive species that causes significant damage to economically important food crops such as blueberries, raspberries, and cherries. SWD is a successful invader as it can lay eggs into fruit by using its serrated ovipositor to penetrate the fruit surface. Ultimately the host fruit provides nutrition to the developing SWD larvae, and makes it unavailable for human consumption. Native to eastern Asia, SWD was first detected on the island of Oahu in the Hawaiian Islands in the early 1980s. Since then, SWD has spread to the major islands and has used several native plants for its reproductive activities.

The primary objective of the Fellow’s research is to identify the evolutionary mechanisms that have enabled SWD to invade and adapt to a novel ecosystem. Specifically, the Fellow determined the effect of ecological variability on SWD population genetic structure and adaptive genetic variation. Elucidating the mechanisms that drive a biological invasion will increase the fundamental understanding of the genetic processes that promote the persistence of invasive species. To examine population genetic diversity patterns of SWD populations in Hawaii, the Fellow used reduced representation genome sequencing technology, bioinformatics techniques, and field surveys. SWD is a fantastic model species to study invasion as they have a quick generation time, and is globally distributed. The results of the Fellow’s research have broad impact in invasive species management, evolutionary biology, and population genetic theory.

In this study, the Fellow discovered evidence for microevolution across invasive SWD populations in Hawaii. Specifically, the Fellow uncovered three distinct genetic clusters of SWD to inhabit 1) Oahu+Kauai, 2) Maui, and 3) Hawaii. This result suggests that SWD populations are in the beginning stages of being isolated from one other, relative to their island of origin. In addition to data that supports the result of fine genetic differentiation across the Hawaiian Islands, the Fellow also discovered signatures of selection only in the fastest evolving parts of the genome. After aligning the SWD genomic data to the Drosophila melanogaster genome, the Fellow found significant genetic differentiation (WC FST) for several loci on the X chromosome. The X chromosome is a sex chromosome, and has been identified to have a special connection with the process of speciation. Finally, an examination of wing size variation found that SWD populations at cooler, high elevation field sites (>1500 m) have larger wings than populations at warmer, low elevation field sites (<1500 m). This result suggests that SWD has a flexible phenotype (i.e., wing size) and has adapted to the different environments it has invaded. Ultimately, the Fellow has learned that the invasion of SWD in Hawaii is in the early stages of adapting to a diverse environment as supported by patterns of genetic differentiation, rapid evolution, and phenotype variability.

In addition to research, the Fellow pursued activities to enhance his skillset in undergraduate and graduate student teaching, mentoring, and community engagement. Ultimately, the training received as a Fellow has prepared him to pursue a career in biology as university professor where he can integrate research, education, and science outreach opportunities into his laboratory. The training objectives designed in his project have prepared the Fellow to work with students in conducting interdisciplinary research with genomic data and diverse arthropod systems. Finally, mentoring students from underrepresented students in STEM enabled the Fellow to synthesize a teaching philosophy that is inclusive and encourages diverse perspectives.
